meta.ogTitle: Erti Eri Blog — Georgia without rush: routes, wine, cuisine
meta.ogDescription: Short, useful articles: what to see in Tbilisi, how to choose a winery tasting, where to eat well, and how to travel comfortably in Georgia.

pageSubtitle: Routes, Tbilisi, wine, food and tips — to make your trip smooth, safe and beautiful.

articles.title: Top 10 places in Tbilisi: a calm 1–2 day route
articles.excerpt: Old Town, sulfur baths, viewpoints and spots where Tbilisi feels real. Perfect for a short stay.
content: Tbilisi is all about vibe: courtyards, balconies, narrow streets and a modern pace.
Start with Abanotubani and the Old Town, then Narikala fortress for the best panoramas. End the day with a wine bar or dinner with a view.
To add depth: a morning market, a small cellar tasting, and one or two modern districts.

articles.title: Georgian wine: qvevri and 8,000 years of tradition
articles.excerpt: Why a family winery tasting feels deeper than a standard tour: qvevri, terroirs, grapes and atmosphere.
content: Georgia is one of the world’s historic wine regions — backed by archaeological evidence.
Qvevri are clay vessels buried in the ground, creating a layered, “alive” taste profile.
Best format: tasting with the host — wine, story, proper serving and local snacks.

articles.title: Georgian food guide: what to try and where
articles.excerpt: Beyond khinkali and khachapuri: regional differences, seasonal dishes and how to avoid tourist traps.
content: Georgian cuisine is about regions, traditions and seasonality — not a single universal list.
Classics matter, but the real magic is in sauces, vegetables, spices and home-style serving.
Simple rule: if locals eat there — it’s usually honest and delicious.

articles.title: Svaneti trekking: how to prepare and what to choose
articles.excerpt: Towers, glaciers and cinematic routes. First-timer tips: pace, clothing, weather and logistics.
content: Svaneti is scale and emotion: peaks, fog, towers and a true adventure feeling.
For your first trip, pick moderate routes with guesthouses — comfortable and atmospheric.
Weather changes fast: proper shoes, layering, and time buffer are essential.

articles.title: First time in Georgia: 7 practical tips for comfort
articles.excerpt: How to plan without stress: transport, money, connectivity and habits that make travel easy.
content: Plan around 2–3 base locations and one strong day trip (mountains / wine / sea).
Between cities, comfort often matters more than saving — train or private transfer helps a lot.
Don’t try to do everything — Georgia is best when you actually live the moments.
